image.altText: Generic Australian Federal Police

items.synopsis: The Gold Coast man, 45, has been charged with 136 counts of rape and 110 counts of sexual intercourse with a child under 10.

title.children: Former childcare worker charged with 1,623 child abuse offences against 91 children

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: The RBA has left interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent. It leaves the cash rate at its highest level since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: RBA warns another rate hike may be on the cards despite holding off in August

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What's the best approach for those homeowners whose fixed rate mortgages will expire shortly. Fix again for 1 or 2 years or move to a flexible rate? - Tim. Hey Tim, We can't provide you advice on what the best course of action is to take with your mortgage — we aren't licensed to do so (it's also why we have that little disclaimer at the top of the blog). That said, there are thousands of home owners who are coming off their fixed rate and are bracing for the impact of these higher rates. A couple of months ago our colleague Stephanie Chalmers pulled together this handy guide if you're already struggling with mortgage repayments. But if you're trying to get ahead of the curve, we've also got you covered. Emily Stewart asked the experts this very question last year, and pulled together this quick guide to help you prepare — and who to ask for advice. I've linked it below for you to have a read of (or you can bookmark it for another day).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: My fixed rate mortgage is expiring soon, what is the best approach?

featuredLink.title: 'Start preparing for the mortgage cliff while you can', experts warn fixed rate borrowers

children.content: What's the best approach for those homeowners whose fixed rate mortgages will expire shortly. Fix again for 1 or 2 years or move to a flexible rate?
- Tim
Hey Tim,
We can't provide you advice on what the best course of action is to take with your mortgage — we aren't licensed to do so (it's also why we have that little disclaimer at the top of the blog).
That said, there are thousands of home owners who are coming off their fixed rate and are bracing for the impact of these higher rates.
A couple of months ago our colleague
Stephanie Chalmers
pulled together
this handy guide if you're already struggling with mortgage repayments

But if you're trying to get ahead of the curve, we've also got you covered. Emily Stewart asked the experts this very question last year, and pulled together this quick guide to help you prepare — and who to ask for advice.
I've linked it below for you to have a read of (or you can bookmark it for another day).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Hi Kate and Sue.
I note that the RBA statement says inflation is modelled "to be back within the 2–3 per cent target range in late 2025". That's 2½ years. So can we expect that there will be no cuts in the target inflation rate for another 2½ to 3 years? Or is the Bank likely to start cutting before the target band is reached? 3 years is a long time to absorb the current minimum repayments. - Luke - Perth. Hi Luke, thanks for writing in. Currently, annual inflation is sitting at 6%, which is double the highest level the RBA is willing to tolerate. The RBA is expecting we won't see inflation in that range until 2025, and that's because inflation is a really pesky thing to try and bring down, and it takes a lot of time. Inflation is often referred to as "sticky" because it sticks around at those higher levels — and you only have to look at the past 18 months or so to see just how rapidly inflation surged in the economy, and how it's only just now cooling off. Quarterly inflation figures from the ABS show inflation only peaked at 7.8% in the three months to December last year — several months after the RBA started lifting rates. To keep it simple, the RBA is using a bunch of economic data to model when inflation might come back to that 2-3% range it wants, which is where it's getting that late-2025 date from. But to get us to that point at all, the theory goes that higher rates need to be sustained to suppress spending — which is why we won't be seeing any rate cuts any time soon. For what it's worth though, last month the major banks were expecting the first round of rate cuts sometime in 2024 — although that was their position before inflation data was released. It's also worth pointing out that the RBA itself has (very intentionally) not given a time frame to when rate cuts might happen.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How long before the RBA starts to cut rates?

children.content:
Hi Kate and Sue.
I note that the RBA statement says inflation is modelled "to be back within the 2–3 per cent target range in late 2025". That's 2½ years. So can we expect that there will be no cuts in the target inflation rate for another 2½ to 3 years? Or is the Bank likely to start cutting before the target band is reached? 3 years is a long time to absorb the current minimum repayments.
- Luke - Perth
Hi Luke, thanks for writing in.
Currently, annual inflation is sitting at 6%, which is double the highest level the RBA is willing to tolerate.
The RBA is expecting we won't see inflation in that range until 2025, and that's because
inflation is a really pesky thing to try and bring down
, and it takes a lot of time.
Inflation is often referred to as "sticky" because it sticks around
at those higher levels — and you only have to look at the past 18 months or so to see just how rapidly inflation surged in the economy, and how it's only just now cooling off.
Quarterly inflation figures from the ABS show
inflation only peaked at 7.8% in the three months to December
last year — several months
after
the RBA started lifting rates.
To keep it simple, the RBA is using a bunch of economic data to model when inflation might come back to that 2-3% range it wants, which is where it's getting that late-2025 date from.
But to get us to that point at all, the theory goes that
higher rates need to be sustained to suppress spending
— which is why we won't be seeing any rate cuts any time soon.
For what it's worth though, last month the major banks were expecting the
first round of rate cuts sometime in 2024
— although that was their position
before
inflation data was released.
It's also worth pointing out that the RBA itself has (very intentionally) not given a time frame to when rate cuts might happen.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: RBA governor Philip Lowe used his statement to note that services inflation is going to be a key focus for the central bank going forward, and noting that it's been "surprisingly persistent" overseas — and is concerned the same might occur here. So what is services inflation, and why is the RBA concerned about it? It's simply referring to how much the prices of services (think hairdressing, vet services, insurance) are rising — and last week's inflation data from the ABS showed that services inflation was gathering pace while goods inflation was falling. You can see the divergence between the two below: The ABS said inflation in the prices for services recorded its largest annual rise since 2001, driven by higher prices in a range of services categories including rents, restaurant meals, holiday travel and insurance. Services inflation is now running at 6.3%, up from 6.1% in the March quarter. So it's still heading higher, but goods inflation is definitely heading down — it's at 5.8%, down from 7.6% in March.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Briskly' rising services inflation a key focus for the RBA going forward

children.content: RBA governor Philip Lowe used his statement to note that services inflation is going to be a key focus for the central bank going forward, and noting that it's been "surprisingly persistent" overseas — and is concerned the same might occur here.
So what is services inflation, and why is the RBA concerned about it?
It's simply referring to how much the prices of services (think hairdressing, vet services, insurance) are rising — and last week's inflation data from the ABS showed that
services inflation was gathering pace while goods inflation was falling.
You can see the divergence between the two below:
The ABS said
inflation in the prices for services recorded its largest annual rise since 2001
, driven by higher prices in a range of services categories
including rents, restaurant meals, holiday travel and insurance.
Services inflation is now running at 6.3%
, up from 6.1% in the March quarter.
So it's still heading higher, but
goods inflation is definitely heading down
— it's at 5.8%, down from 7.6% in March.

image.altText: A desert kurrajong tree sits against a purple night sky.

items.synopsis: Against the dry, arid landscapes of west and central Australia, these trees not only catch your eye, but are a source of food and water and can point you in the right direction if you're lost.

title.children: The desert kurrajong looks like a child's drawing of a tree, but in the outback it can be a lifesaver

image.altText: Two men next to a beach

items.synopsis: What's going on with the weather in Australia? It's partly the result of natural drivers of our weather – and partly due to global warming, writes Andrew King.

title.children: Why is Australia having such a warm winter?

image.altText: An out of focus man and woman walk past a building with glass sliding doors and a sign reading Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank leaves interest rates on hold for the second month in a row, raising questions about whether it may be finished hiking borrowing costs.

title.children: RBA leaves interest rates on hold for second consecutive month

image.altText: David Rosengren speaking.

items.synopsis: Chief Operating Officer David Rosengren is leaving the job effective immediately, meaning he will be unavailable to support Shannon Fentiman at this week's estimates hearings.

title.children: Another bombshell resignation for the Queensland government as it gears up for 2024 election

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt and glasses stand in a field in front of a huge antenna.

items.synopsis: NASA's giant dish antenna in Canberra is on the lookout for signals from the Voyager 2 spacecraft, after flight controllers accidentally severed communications more than a week ago.

title.children: Canberra dish on lookout for lost Voyager 2 spacecraft

image.altText: Corporal Alex Naggs (left), Lieutenant Maxwell Nugent (middle) and Warrant Officer Class 2 Joseph Laycock.

items.synopsis: Warrant Officer Joseph "Phillip" Laycock, Corporal Alexander Naggs and Lieutenant Maxwell Nugent were three of the four men believed to have died when their army MRH90 Taipan helicopter crashed into the water off north Queensland last week.

title.children: Loved ones release statements honouring men who died in Taipan chopper crash

image.altText: Anne Pedler with two young boys.

items.synopsis: A coroner blasts a Tasmanian hospital over the death of a woman, noting her illness was "underestimated in the extreme" and that she spent eight hours in an ambulance outside the facility as "no bed [was] available for her" due to a "lack of nursing staff on duty".

title.children: 'There was no-one there for her': Daughter mourns mum as coroner lashes hospital where 71yo died while ramped

image.altText: A woman holding a phone to take a photo hit by a wave.

items.synopsis: Footage shows Beijing's streets becoming rivers and residents being pulled from submerged cars as the remnants of Typhoon Doksuri bring record downpours to Northern China.

title.children: In pictures: Scenes of devastation and dramatic rescues as extreme rain batters China

image.altText: Two middle-aged women walk up the stairs of the NT Supreme Court in Darwin

items.synopsis: A mother and son duo who tried to cover-up the hit-and-run death of an Aboriginal woman have pleaded guilty to a string of serious charges.

title.children: Mother and son admit to criminal cover up of fatal hit and run after discovery of woman's leg

image.altText: Charlie Read looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: The son of one of Australia's most notorious criminals pleads not guilty to drugs, stealing and gun charges over an arrest in Hobart earlier this year.

title.children: Son of Chopper pleads not guilty to gun, drug offences after road spike arrest

image.altText: A man in a black jacket takes a selfie at the top of a high rise building.

items.synopsis: It is believed he was last seen alive knocking on a penthouse window of the building on Thursday.

title.children: Internet-famous French daredevil reported dead in fall from Hong Kong apartment building

image.altText: Michael and Sam, wearing green formal wear, are surrounded by green and gold balloons.

items.synopsis: Samantha Lilly first competed in the World Dwarf Games in 2009, bringing home a swag of medals in the pool. This year she's returning as the Australian team's co-captain, alongside Michael Spain.

title.children: Why Samantha is filled with pride to lead Australia's team at the World Dwarf Games

image.altText: The Aboriginal flag and the Australian flag atop the Sydney Harbour Bridge

items.synopsis: Voter disinterest and confusion are threatening to create an uninformed outcome on the Voice referendum, researchers warn.

title.children: Calls for non-Indigenous Australians to research the Voice to avoid turning 'apathy into a vote'

image.altText: Paul McCarthy live in Glastonbury, with John Lennon behind him.

items.synopsis: Legendary musician Paul McCartney has announced he will bring his Got Back tour to Australia in October with Newcastle and the Gold Coast in the line-up.

title.children: Paul McCartney to visit regional cities for first time on upcoming Australian tour

image.altText: Angus Cloud, dressed in a purple top, clasps his hands together on the red carpet.

items.synopsis: The actor, best known for playing drug dealer Fezco in HBO show Euphoria, has died aged 25.

title.children: Euphoria actor Angus Cloud dies

image.altText: Hunter Biden, wearing suits, departs federal court after a plea hearing

items.synopsis: Hunter Biden would often put his famous father on speakerphone to impress clients and business associates, a congressional probe has heard. However, the current US president was never directly involved in their financial dealings. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: Hunter Biden accused of creating 'illusion of access' to Joe Biden during business dealings

image.altText: Rain falling over ocean with mountains in background

items.synopsis: The weather bureau is forecasting more rain across northern Queensland this week to the dismay of farmers and tourism authorities.

title.children: Unseasonably wet winter a dampener for far north farmers, tourists still roll in

image.altText: For sale sign outside an apartment building along a street in Brisbane

items.synopsis: Brisbane house values rose 4.2 per cent over the three months to the end of July, making it tied with Adelaide for the greatest growth that month.

title.children: Vendors back in control: Brisbane one of the top cities when it comes to growth in housing prices

image.altText: A young girl with dark black hair, wearing jeans and a denim jacket, sits cross legged and smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Tarikjot Singh, who abducted his ex-girlfriend Jasmeen Kaur from her Adelaide workplace and then buried her alive in the Flinders Ranges, is jailed for the murder, with the sentencing judge saying he could not find words to describe the young woman's final moments.

title.children: Man jailed for 'horrific' murder of ex-girlfriend Jasmeen Kaur in outback SA

image.altText: White banner saying "another sold" following house sale

items.synopsis: House prices continue to rise, but there are further signs that a recent rebound may be losing steam as spring selling season approaches and the appeal of life outside the cities fades post-pandemic.

title.children: Premium property markets are no longer booming and it 'could be a sign of broader easing'

image.altText: Philip Lowe giving evidence, resting his head on his hand.

items.synopsis: Inflation might be rapidly falling, but economists will stick to their textbooks to argue another rate rise is needed. It's little wonder why it's earned the reputation of being the dismal science, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Inflation is falling rapidly — but economists are ignoring the signs because their textbooks tell them to

image.altText: A women's soccer team wearing light blue uniforms runs to the sideline celebrating

items.synopsis: With their greatest-ever Women's World Cup victory, the Matildas have shown they are so much more than just Sam Kerr.

title.children: Without their biggest star, the Matildas' win over Canada showed us who they really are

image.altText: Ben Stokes and Pat Cummins smile

items.synopsis: A lot has happened over the past seven weeks during this Ashes series. Here are some of the key moments from each nailbiting Test.

title.children: Possibly the greatest Ashes series of all time just finished. Here's how it went down

items.synopsis: Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin says a number of drones were downed but one successfully hit a building that was struck earlier in the week.

title.children: Moscow mayor accuses Ukraine of drone strike on city buildings

image.altText: a cow with lesions all over its skin.

items.synopsis: Queensland has been left without its only operating export depot to Indonesia after its government suspended live cattle imports from four Australian export facilities amid lumpy skin disease infections.

title.children: Qld without Indonesian live export facility following saleyards suspension

image.altText: Shannon Hurn raises his right arm to celebrate the West Coast Eagles beating Collingwood in the AFL grand final.

items.synopsis: West Coast Eagles games record holder and 2018 premiership captain Shannon Hurn announces his retirement from the AFL.

title.children: 'I'm really going to miss it': West Coast Eagles premiership captain Shannon Hurn announces retirement

image.altText: People walk past a film poster featuring a man in a metallic red and gold suit with Chinese characters

items.synopsis: Hollywood films can make millions at the Chinese box office. What influence is the massive market having on films made in both locations?

title.children: 'China will punish a company': Is Hollywood playing a risky game with China?

image.altText: Alanna Kennedy and Katrina Gorry wearing blue Matildas away jerseys, celebrating their win

items.synopsis: We won't know who the Matildas will play next until after tonight's matches, but we know where they'll be playing — and what colours they'll be wearing.

title.children: What we know about the Matildas' next game
